The authors acknowledge the Programme d’investissements d’avenir (PIA) in France for funding with the grant ANR-18-MOPGA-0009 and the Occitanie Region.BiographiesKarim Adil holds a PhD in solid-state chemistry (2005) from Le Mans University (France). Since 2006, he is professor of chemistry in the Institute of Molecules and Materials of Le Mans. In 2021, he obtained his habilitation to conduct research. His work is mainly dedicated to the elaboration and characterization of new MOFs materials for gas related applications and especially gas separation. Katarzyna Świrk holds double Ph.D. title from Sorbonne Université (France) and AGH University of Science and Technology (Poland) for her work on yttrium promoted nickel hydrotalcite-derived catalysts for chemical CO2 utilization. In October 2019, she started postdoctoral position at ICGM, Université de Montpellier on the project to Make Our Planet Great Again. From October 2020, Katarzyna Świrk works as a postdoctoral researcher under Marie Skłodowska-Curie Individual Fellowship at Norwegian University of Science and Technology (Norway).Abdelali Zaki obtained his Ph.D from University of Lille (France) in 2014. He joined as postdoctoral fellow different international research institutes, Masdar institute in Abu Dhabi, UAE (2016), CIC EnergiGUNE, Spain (2017), University of Montpellier (2019) and University of Orleans, France (2020). Currently, he is a postdoctoral researcher at University of Le Mans (France), his research activities are focused mainly on design of functional and porous materials for catalytic, energy storage and solar fuel applications.Ayalew H. Assen is a postdoctoral researcher at Mohammed VI Polytechnic University. He received his Ph.D. degree from King Abdullah University of Science and Technology. He obtained his double M.Sc. degrees, one in Advanced Spectroscopy in Chemistry from University of Lille I and Universität Leipzig (Erasmus Mundus program) and the other in Organic chemistry from Addis Ababa University. His research is focused on design and preparation of metal-organic frameworks for gas/liquid separation, sensing, and other applications.Gérard Delahay has obtained his PhD at University of Lille in 1984. In 1988, after several postdoctoral positions, he joined, as CNRS researcher, the Laboratory for Coordination Chemistry in Toulouse where he focussed on oxibronzes for catalytic applications. Then he moved to Montpellier where he started to develop catalysis for air pollution control. Since 2008, he has been CNRS research director at the Charles Gerhardt Institute in Montpellier.Dr Youssef Belmabkhout is a Full Professor at Mohammed VI polytechnic University. He has a PhD in Applied Sciences from the University of Mons (Belgium) and hold also a Chemical Engineering degree from the Gubkine Russian State University in Moscow (Russia). His doctoral expertise covers various aspects of reactive and non-reactive adsorption. He has been recognized among most cited researchers in the world by Web of Sciences in 2019 and 2020 and 2021.Amandine Cadiau holds a PhD in solid-state chemistry from Le Mans University (2010). After several post-doctoral positions (in Prof. Rocha, Serre, Eddaoudi, Gascon groups), she joined the Charles Gerhardt Institute in Montpellier (2018). Her work is mainly focused on the synthesis and crystallographic characterisation of MOF materials.
